case_id: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Rayavarapu Punnayya (1976) 4 SCC 382 / AIR 1977 SC 45
facts: Accused No. 1 (A-1, Rayavarapu Punnayya) and Accused No. 2 (A-2, Rayavarapu Jaggaraju) were charged in connection with the death of Jagannadham.
A quarrel took place between A-1, A-2 and the deceased (Jagannadham).
During the quarrel, A-1 stabbed the deceased with a spear ('barchi') in the abdomen.
The injury caused was a single penetrating wound to the abdomen.
The deceased was hospitalized and received medical treatment.
The deceased died on June 20, 1969, seven days after the incident.
Medical evidence (post-mortem report) established the cause of death as peritonitis and secondary shock resulting from the spear injury to the abdomen.

The Trial Court acquitted A-1 of the charge under Section 302 IPC, but convicted him under Section 324 IPC (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons). A-2 was also convicted under Section 324 IPC.
The State of Andhra Pradesh appealed the acquittal of A-1 under Section 302 IPC to the High Court.

The High Court allowed the State's appeal, set aside the acquittal under Section 302 IPC, and convicted A-1 under Section 302 IPC, sentencing him to life imprisonment. The High Court maintained A-2's conviction under Section 324 IPC.
A-1 (Rayavarapu Punnayya) appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court.
ipc_sections: Section 304 (Punishment for Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder - Parts I and II)
Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means)

prosecution_arguments.argument: A-1's act constitutes Murder under Section 300, Clause Thirdly. He intentionally caused a bodily injury (spear thrust to abdomen) which was objectively sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.
precedents: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)
Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148)
State of A.P. v. M. Sobhan Babu (2000) 10 SCC 481
elements: Intention to cause bodily injury (specific injury inflicted).
Nature of the injury (penetrating spear wound to vital area - abdomen).
Sufficiency of the injury to cause death in the ordinary course of nature (supported by medical evidence linking injury to peritonitis and death).

counter_arguments.loophole: Defense may argue lack of specific intention to cause an injury *sufficient to cause death*, only intention to cause injury, bringing it under Sec 299/304.
supporting_precedents: Jagrup Singh v. State of Haryana (1981) 3 SCC 616
Harjinder Singh v. Delhi Administration (AIR 1968 SC 867)

counter_arguments.loophole: Defense may invoke Exception 4 to Section 300 (Sudden Fight).
supporting_precedents: Surain Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1976 SC 2169)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. (2003) 3 SCC 528

prosecution_arguments.argument: The High Court correctly reversed the Trial Court's acquittal under Sec 302, as the Trial Court failed to appreciate the gravity of the intended injury and its sufficiency to cause death.
precedents: Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (on powers of appellate court in appeals against acquittal)
State of Rajasthan v. Ram Prasad (2001) 3 SCC 333 (Interference with acquittal justified if view taken by trial court is perverse or clearly erroneous)
elements: Incorrect application of law (distinction between Sec 300/304) by Trial Court.
Medical evidence strongly indicating sufficiency of injury for causing death.
Lack of mitigating circumstances reducing offence from murder.

counter_arguments.loophole: Appellate courts should be slow to interfere with acquittal unless the trial court view is wholly unreasonable.
supporting_precedents: Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154
Ramesh Babulal Doshi v. State of Gujarat (1996) 9 SCC 225

defense_arguments.argument: The act falls under Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder (Section 304 IPC), likely Part II. A-1 lacked the specific intention required for Section 300 Clause Thirdly; he may have had knowledge that the act was likely to cause death, but not the intention to cause an injury sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.
edge_cases: Single blow nature of the assault.
precedents: Chamru Budhwa v. State of Madhya Pradesh (AIR 1954 SC 652)
Gurmail Singh v. State of Punjab (1982) 3 SCC 185)
Randhir Singh @ Dhire v. State of Punjab (2004) 13 SCC 129 (discussing distinction between 302 and 304)

defense_arguments.argument: Alternatively, the case is covered by Exception 4 to Section 300 (Sudden Fight). The incident arose out of a sudden quarrel, occurred in the heat of passion, and A-1 did not take undue advantage or act in a cruel or unusual manner (single blow).
edge_cases: Proving absence of 'undue advantage' (e.g., relative armament, deceased's position).
Arguing a single spear thrust, though dangerous, was not 'cruel or unusual' in the context of a sudden fight.
precedents: Sukhbir Singh v. State of Haryana (2002) 3 SCC 327
Surain Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1976 SC 2169)
Ghapoo Yadav v. State of M.P. (2003) 3 SCC 528

defense_arguments.argument: The High Court erred in reversing the acquittal under Section 302. The Trial Court's view convicting under Section 324 was a possible and reasonable interpretation of the facts and intent.
edge_cases: Standard for reversing acquittal (requires perversity or gross error).
Trial court had advantage of observing witnesses (though less relevant here as facts largely undisputed).
precedents: Ajit Singh Thakur Singh v. State of Gujarat (AIR 1981 SC 733)
Ayodhya Singh v. State of Bihar (AIR 1974 SC 1880)
Basappa v. State of Karnataka (2014) 5 SCC 154

judgment.outcome: Conviction altered from Section 302 IPC (Murder) to Section 304 Part II IPC (Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder).
reasoning: The Supreme Court undertook a detailed analysis distinguishing Culpable Homicide (Sec 299) and Murder (Sec 300).

The court clarified that while the injury was dangerous and caused death, the evidence suggested A-1 possessed the 'knowledge' that his act (stabbing with a spear in the abdomen) was likely to cause death (fitting Sec 299 Clause (c)).

The court found that the specific 'intention' required for Murder under Sec 300 Clause Thirdly (intention to cause bodily injury sufficient *in the ordinary course of nature* to cause death) was not proven beyond reasonable doubt.

The distinction lies in the degree of probability or likelihood of death resulting from the intended act. While the act was culpable homicide, it did not meet the higher threshold of intention specified in Sec 300, Clause Thirdly, as interpreted in Virsa Singh.
The court likely considered the single blow and the context of the quarrel, inferring knowledge rather than the specific intent required for murder.

Therefore, the act constituted Culpable Homicide not amounting to Murder, punishable under Section 304 Part II IPC, which applies when the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death, or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death.
cited_cases: Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab (AIR 1958 SC 465)
Anda v. State of Rajasthan (AIR 1966 SC 148)
Rajwant Singh v. State of Kerala (AIR 1966 SC 1874)
State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup (AIR 1974 SC 1570)
